column1: Doncaster East is a suburb of Melbourne
column4: 20 km north-east of Melbourne's Central Business District in the local government area of the City of Manningham. At the 2016 Census
column5: Doncaster East had a population of 28
column6: 360.It is located in the hills between the Koonung Creek and the Mullum Mullum Creek.

column1: The area was originally occupied by the Wurundjeri
column2: Indigenous Australians of the Kulin nation
column3: who spoke variations of the Woiwurrung language group. After European settlement
column4: the area was used for agriculture
column5: predominantly orchards. A small settlement was established in the 1860s
column7: which was home to many German settlers
column8: who planted the large areas of pine trees that still exist today. German Lane was the original name for George Street
column9: and Bismarck Street the original name for Victoria Street. The names were replaced during the First World War and the present names adopted.

column1: The Post Office opened on 8 August 1887. A Tunstall Square office was open from 1965 until 1990.Like much of the City of Manningham
column2: Doncaster East was predominantly covered in fruit orchards for some time before subdivision began and it became a contiguous part of Melbourne. Housing estates began to replace orchards in the 1960s
column4: in the southern half of the suburb. The north half of the suburb was developed through the 1970s and 1980s
column5: with the last orchard being removed in the 1990s. As the young parents who moved into these estates now retire and move away
column6: many houses from the 60s and 70s are being converted into units.

column1: The area of land that is occupied by Doncaster East mostly consists of rolling hills
column2: creek valleys and short ridges. Andersons Creek Road runs along an unnamed ridge that
column4: gives views of Mount Dandenong to the east and the further rolling hills of Templestowe to the west.

column1: Three main watercourses flow through or border the suburb:
Ruffey CreekThe native vegetation of Doncaster East has been almost totally cleared
column2: notable exceptions being the north-east of the suburb around the Mullum Mullum Creek
column3: where small areas of native riparian bushland remain. Many small areas of Pine Trees were planted by early German settlers and can be found all over the suburb
column4: particularly around George and Victoria Streets and to the south-east
column5: in many places they were used as wind breaks or property boundaries for agriculture and serve as a good indicator of historical property boundaries. Many European deciduous trees were planted in the 1970s and 1980s and have since matured on roadsides and on private properties. Invasive species remain as one of the suburbs major environmental problems.

column1: The suburb boundaries roughly form the shape of an L flipped horizontally
column3: Victoria Street and Blackburn Road to the west
column6: Springvale Road and Tunstall Road in the east
column7: adjoining Warrandyte and Donvale and the Koonung Creek to the south
column8: adjoining Blackburn North. The north-east section of the suburb sits on the western side of the Mullum Mullum Valley and is very occasionally referred to as being whole or part of West Warrandyte and rarer still
column9: East Templestowe. There are many small anecdotal localities that have established individual community identities within the suburb

column1: Donburn - Around the Blackburn Road/Doncaster Road intersection.
Deep Creek - The northernmost area of the suburb
Tunstall - Around Tunstall Square and Tunstall Road.

column1: The Pines - The area north of The Pines Shopping Centre.
Doncaster East has had a significant Chinese minority for many years. Therefore
column2: there are a number of Chinese restaurants

column1: Public transportation in the City of Manningham consists of regular bus services that cover most of the suburb. Plans for a railway line to Doncaster East were scrapped by the Cain Labor Government and as a result local residents rely heavily on the use of cars.

The suburb is serviced primarily by the Eastern Freeway to the south and Reynolds Road in the north. Through traffic consists primarily of cars and buses traveling to neighbouring Warrandyte and Donvale through the use of Heidelberg - Warrandyte Road
column2: Reynolds Road and Tindals Road (Old Warrandyte Road)
Doncaster East is serviced by George Street
column3: King Street and Victoria Street. Running north-south is Blackburn Road
column4: which holds most of the flow of traffic during weekday peak hour times
column6: as residents travel from their homes to the Eastern Freeway and into the city.

column4: established in 1997 through the merging of Waldau Primary School and Doncaster East Primary School.

column2: which extends the Eastern Freeway to Ringwood and then south to join with the Monash and Mornington Peninsula Freeways
column3: was completed and opened in 2008. It enables residents of Doncaster East increased ease of travel when travelling through Melbourne's eastern and south-eastern suburbs.

column1: Certain areas of land are currently awaiting development
column2: including the former Box Hill Institute of TAFE's East Doncaster campus
column3: now a newly subdivided small housing estate and a large area surrounding the Cherry Hill Tavern
column4: which is proposed for a reception centre.

column1: There are several vacant blocks of land in the suburb
column2: many surrounding The Pines Shopping Centre. Various uses have been proposed and many applications for restaurants or fast food providers have been met with opposition from surrounding residents.

column1: Many people are active members of certain clubs or facilities in Doncaster East. Popular activities include Scouts
column7: Bike Riding and Dog Walking. The waters of the Mullum Mullum Creek are too shallow for swimming in the summer months
column9: this does not stop exploration or walks on the paths around the creek.

column1: Doncaster Rovers Soccer Club (not to be confused with the English club of the same name) are based in Doncaster East. Founded in 1967
column2: the club currently plays in Football Federation Victoria State League 2 South-East. The club plays its home games at Anderson Park.

column1: The suburb also has an Australian Rules football team
column3: competing in the Eastern Football League. The Manningham Cricket Club plays at Rieschiecks Reserve and competes in the Eastern Cricket Association MacGibbon Shield. The East Doncaster Cricket Club plays at Zerbes Reserve and competes in the Eastern Cricket Association Dunstan Shield (Turf).
